description: From Middle English feynen, feinen, borrowed from Old French feindre (“to pretend”), from Latin fingere (“to form, shape, invent”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeyǵʰ- (“to mold”). Compare French feignant (present participle of feindre, literally “feigning”). Also compare feint and fiction.

verbs.description: feign (third-person singular simple present feigns, present participle feigning, simple past and past participle feigned)

entries.meaning: To make a false show or pretence of; to counterfeit or simulate.
examples: The pupil feigned sickness on the day of his exam.
They feigned her signature on the cheque.

entries.meaning: To imagine; to invent; to pretend to do something.
examples: He feigned that he had gone home at the appointed time.

entries.meaning: To make an action as if doing one thing, but actually doing another, for example to trick an opponent; to feint.

examples: Jessica feigned the fact that she had not done her homework.
